title: How to make your writing suspenseful - Victoria Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to suspense in a story, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It sets up a question that the audience hopes to get an answer to and delays that answer while maintaining their interest.

options.label: B
options.text: It reveals the dark secret to the characters, but not to the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sense of closure and emotional release.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in horror films and mystery novels.

multiple-choice.question: Which technique is used to create suspense by revealing key parts of the big secret to the audience but not to the characters?

options.label: A
options.text: Limiting the point of view.

options.label: B
options.text: Playing with style and form.

options.label: C
options.text: Using dramatic irony.

options.label: D
options.text: Creating a cliffhanger.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using a cliffhanger in a story, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of closure and emotional release.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the audience feel bored and uninterested.

options.label: C
options.text: It builds extra suspense and makes the audience worry and wonder what will happen next.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in horror films and mystery novels.

multiple-choice.question: Which classic novel is an example of a story told through letters and diary entries?

options.label: A
options.text: "Dracula".

options.label: B
options.text: "Rebecca".

options.label: C
options.text: "The Tell-Tale Heart".

options.label: D
options.text: "Oedipus Rex".

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using ordinary places and objects in a story to make them sinister, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of comfort and security.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the story feel boring and uninteresting.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sense of unease and discomfort.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in horror films and mystery novels.

title: Why should you read James Joyce's "Ulysses"? - Sam Slote

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the day when thousands of people all over the world dress up like the characters from James Joyce's "Ulysses" and read the book aloud?

options.label: A
options.text: Bloomsday

options.label: B
options.text: Ulysses Day

options.label: C
options.text: Joyce Day

options.label: D
options.text: Literary Day

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the remarkable things about James Joyce's "Ulysses" that keeps people coming back to read it?

options.label: A
options.text: Its easy-to-follow plot

options.label: B
options.text: Its unique writing style

options.label: C
options.text: Its lack of literary references

options.label: D
options.text: Its short length

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the literary movement characterized by overturning traditional modes of writing, and to which James Joyce's "Ulysses" is a key text?

options.label: A
options.text: Literary Modernism

options.label: B
options.text: Postmodernism

options.label: C
options.text: Realism

options.label: D
options.text: Romanticism

options.label: A
options.text: Stephen Dedalus

options.label: B
options.text: Leopold Bloom

options.label: C
options.text: Molly Bloom

options.label: D
options.text: Odysseus

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too long

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was too short

options.label: C
options.text: Because it contained too many literary references

options.label: D
options.text: Because it contained too many sexual references

title: What in the world is topological quantum matter? - Fan Zhang

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the branch of mathematics that focuses on fundamental properties of objects, which don't change when an object is gradually stretched or bent?

options.label: A
options.text: Geometry

options.label: B
options.text: Topology

options.label: C
options.text: Algebra

options.label: D
options.text: Calculus

multiple-choice.question: What is a topological insulator, and what are its unique properties?

options.label: A
options.text: A material that conducts electricity throughout, with no holes or imperfections.

options.label: B
options.text: A material that conducts electricity around its edge, but not in the middle, with perfect electron transport and no energy loss as heat.

options.label: C
options.text: A material that is affected by small changes in its structure, like impurities or imperfections.

options.label: D
options.text: A material that is not affected by temperature or pressure changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using topological properties in quantum computing?

options.label: A
options.text: It would make quantum computers slower and less accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: It would allow for more complex calculations, but with a higher risk of data loss.

options.label: C
options.text: It would create more stable qubits, leading to more accurate computation and a better quantum computer.

options.label: D
options.text: It would make quantum computers more expensive and difficult to build.

multiple-choice.question: What was the discovery made by David Thouless, Duncan Haldane, and Michael Kosterlitz, which led to them winning the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2016?

options.label: A
options.text: That subatomic particles can be in different states at the same time.

options.label: B
options.text: That topological properties exist at the quantum level.

options.label: C
options.text: That the laws of quantum physics are not affected by temperature or pressure changes.

options.label: D
options.text: That the behavior of subatomic particles can be described using classical physics.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential application of the technology that could be built using the properties of topological insulators?

options.label: A
options.text: Building more efficient solar panels.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating more stable and accurate quantum computers.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new materials for construction and architecture.

options.label: D
options.text: Building more efficient and powerful classical computers.

title: Why should you read Virgil's "Aeneid"? - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for Virgil's death?

options.label: A
options.text: He died of old age.

options.label: B
options.text: He died in a battle.

options.label: C
options.text: He died from heatstroke.

options.label: D
options.text: He died of a broken heart.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Augustus interested in saving Virgil's poem, the "Aeneid"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to learn more about Roman history.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to create a poem to rival the "Iliad" and "Odyssey" of Ancient Greece.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to show off his poetic skills.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to earn more money.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of the "Aeneid"?

options.label: A
options.text: The story of a hero who conquers a kingdom.

options.label: B
options.text: The story of a hero who establishes a new home for his people.

options.label: C
options.text: The story of a hero who struggles with his duty and often seems a reluctant hero.

options.label: D
options.text: The story of a hero who dies in a battle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Temple of Janus in the "Aeneid"?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the beginning of the Roman Empire.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the end of the Roman Empire.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the arrival of permanent peace.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the arrival of war.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Augustus only read three selected extracts of the "Aeneid"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was busy with his work.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was not interested in the story.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was only interested in the parts that promoted his achievements.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was not able to read.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the decline of Polynesian voyages by around 1300 A.D.?

options.text: Overpopulation led to a decrease in the number of people willing to embark on voyages.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of modern navigational aids made voyages less challenging.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Using a compass to determine the direction of the magnetic field.

options.label: B
options.text: Observing the position of the Sun and stars to determine the direction of their canoes.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a map to navigate through the Pacific Ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: Following the trade winds to determine the direction of their canoes.

options.label: C

title: Why is it so hard to cure cancer? - Kyuson Yun

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons why cancer is difficult to cure?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells are highly contagious.

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer cells are resistant to treatment.

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer arises as normal cells accumulate mutations.

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer is caused by a single genetic mutation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing new cancer treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells are too aggressive.

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer cells are too slow-growing.

options.label: C
options.text: New treatments often fail in clinical trials with real patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer cells are too difficult to study.

multiple-choice.question: What is clonal heterogeneity in cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of multiple cancerous cells in a single tumor.

options.label: B
options.text: The absence of cancerous cells in a single tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of a single cancerous cell in a single tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of cancerous cells in a tumor ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cancer stem cells in cancer treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the primary target of cancer treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: They are resistant to chemotherapy and radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the source of cancer growth and recurrence.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not relevant to cancer treatment.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key challenges in treating cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer cells are too difficult to target.

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer cells are too easy to target.

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer cells constantly adapt and evolve.

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer cells are too slow-growing.

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: It will only store binary code.

options.label: D

title: Why Facts Don't Convince People (and what you can do about it)

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons why humans are not always rational in their decision-making?

options.label: A
options.text: The human brain is too complex to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans are guided by tribal instinct rather than facts.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans are not capable of making decisions at all.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are only rational when it comes to emotions.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people sometimes react aggressively to information that proves them wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not used to hearing opposing views.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their brain is constantly protecting their worldview and sense of identity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not smart enough to understand the information.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not interested in learning new things.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "backfire effect" that happens when people encounter facts that contradict their current beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more convinced of their original ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less convinced of their original ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain neutral and do not change their beliefs.

options.label: D
options.text: They become angry and dismissive of the information.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to have an intelligent political debate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people are not willing to listen to opposing views.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain is constantly protecting our worldview and sense of identity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people are not interested in learning new things.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to prevent someone's brain from seeing you as a personal threat when presenting factual information that clashes with their beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: By being confrontational and aggressive.

options.label: B
options.text: By finding common ground and identifying yourself as part of their tribe.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring their beliefs and presenting the information anyway.

options.label: D
options.text: By being dismissive of their views and not listening to them.

options.label: C
options.text: He developed abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting, and his stomach was teeming with the same bacteria as his patient.

options.text: He was cured of his stomach ulcers immediately.

multiple-choice.question: What was the misconception about stomach ulcers that Dr. Marshall's idea challenged?

options.label: A
options.text: That ulcers are caused by eating spicy food.

options.label: B
options.text: That ulcers are caused by stress alone.

options.label: C
options.text: That ulcers are caused by a bacterial infection.

options.label: D
options.text: That ulcers are caused by a combination of stress and spicy food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the spiral-shaped bacteria that Dr. Marshall and Dr. Warren pinpointed as the real offender in causing stomach ulcers?

options.label: A
options.text: Helicobacter pylori

options.label: B
options.text: H. pylori

options.label: C
options.text: Stomach Bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: Ulcer Bacteria

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the features that allows H. pylori to survive the acidic environment of the stomach?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces an enzyme called urease that helps protect it from the surrounding gastric acid.

options.label: B
options.text: It produces a protein that helps to neutralize the stomach acid.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a thick layer of mucus that protects it from the stomach acid.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a special type of skin that protects it from the stomach acid.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Dr. Marshall's experiment after he ingested a course of antibiotics similar to the ones taken now for ulcers?

options.label: A
options.text: He developed a severe case of food poisoning.

options.label: B
options.text: He experienced no symptoms at all.

options.label: C
options.text: He was cured of his stomach ulcers.

options.label: D
options.text: He needed surgery to treat his stomach ulcers.

title: Why do we harvest horseshoe crab blood? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: Why do lab workers capture horseshoe crabs on the beach?

options.label: A
options.text: Because that's the only place we know we can find them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are easier to capture in shallow waters.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are more abundant in the ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more active at night.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the blood of horseshoe crabs?

options.label: A
options.text: It contains cells that protect them from infection by viruses, fungi, and bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: It contains cells that protect them from infection by only viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: It contains cells that protect them from infection by only fungi.

options.label: D
options.text: It contains cells that protect them from infection by only bacteria.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the LAL test?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect bacteria in a sample.

options.label: B
options.text: To detect endotoxins in a sample.

options.label: C
options.text: To detect viruses in a sample.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect fungi in a sample.

multiple-choice.question: Why do horseshoe crabs need a sensitive immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a closed circulatory system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have an open circulatory system and their blood flows freely through the body cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they live in a clean ocean and shoreline habitats.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are invincible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of the biomedical industry on horseshoe crabs?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no impact on their populations.

options.label: B
options.text: It has a positive impact on their populations.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a negative impact on their populations, with up to 15% of horseshoe crabs dying in the process of having their blood harvested.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on their populations, but it is used to synthesize horseshoe crab blood in the lab.

title: Is it possible to create a perfect vacuum? - Rolf Landua and Anais Rassat

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of a vacuum, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A space with no matter and energy.

options.label: B
options.text: A space with a low amount of matter and energy.

options.label: C
options.text: A space with no matter, but some energy.

options.label: D
options.text: A space with a normal amount of matter and energy.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists at the Large Hadron Collider create a vacuum for their experiments?

options.label: A
options.text: By using high-powered pumps that create enough suction to remove stray atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a special coating to absorb stray gases and raising the temperature to 200 degrees Celsius.

options.label: C
options.text: By using hundreds of vacuum pumps to trap gas and debris out of the pipes for two weeks.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of quantum fluctuations in the vacuum of space?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the seeds of everything we see today, including galaxies and planets.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the center of one of the greatest scientific mysteries of our time.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the reason why the universe is expanding.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the cause of dark matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between mass and energy, according to Einstein's equations?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass and energy are inversely proportional.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass and energy are equivalent.

options.label: C
options.text: Mass and energy are directly proportional.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass and energy are unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current scientific mystery related to quantum fluctuations in the vacuum of space?

options.label: A
options.text: The mystery of dark matter.

options.label: B
options.text: The mystery of the missing energy.

options.label: C
options.text: The mystery of the expanding universe.

options.label: D
options.text: The mystery of the origins of the universe.

title: How many ways are there to prove the Pythagorean theorem? - Betty Fei

multiple-choice.question: What do Euclid, twelve-year-old Einstein, and American President James Garfield have in common?

options.label: A
options.text: They all came up with elegant proofs for the famous Fibonacci sequence.

options.label: B
options.text: They all came up with elegant proofs for the famous Pythagorean theorem.

options.label: C
options.text: They all came up with elegant proofs for the famous Euclidean geometry.

options.label: D
options.text: They all came up with elegant proofs for the famous Archimedes' principle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Pythagorean theorem, and what does it state?

options.label: A
options.text: The theorem states that the square of one side of a right triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

options.label: B
options.text: The theorem states that the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

options.label: C
options.text: The theorem states that the sum of the squares of the two sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse.

options.label: D
options.text: The theorem states that the product of the two sides of a right triangle is equal to the square of the hypotenuse.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to prove the Pythagorean theorem using tessellation?

options.label: A
options.text: By arranging four identical right triangles into a square and showing that the areas of the triangles are equal to the areas of the square.

options.label: B
options.text: By arranging four identical right triangles into a square and showing that the areas of the triangles are equal to the areas of the square, and then rearranging the triangles into two rectangles.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a repeating geometric pattern of squares and showing that the areas of the squares are equal to the areas of the right triangles.

options.label: D
options.text: By creating a repeating geometric pattern of squares and showing that the areas of the squares are equal to the areas of the right triangles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle that Euclid and twelve-year-old Einstein used to prove the Pythagorean theorem?

options.label: A
options.text: The principle that the sum of the angles of a triangle is always 180 degrees.

options.label: B
options.text: The principle that if the corresponding angles of two triangles are the same, the ratio of their sides is the same, too.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle that the area of a triangle is equal to half the product of the base and the height.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle that the circumference of a circle is always equal to pi times the diameter.

multiple-choice.question: What is one practical application of the Pythagorean theorem?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to calculate the area of a circle.

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to calculate the circumference of a circle.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to construct stable buildings and triangulate GPS coordinates.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to calculate the volume of a sphere.

options.label: B

options.text: Trichomes

options.label: C
options.text: Raphides

options.label: D

options.text: Trichomes

options.label: C
options.text: Lignin

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: How does impeachment work? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between impeachment and removal from office?

options.label: A
options.text: Impeachment is the formal accusation, while removal is the actual process.

options.label: B
options.text: Impeachment is the removal of a government official from office, while removal is the formal accusation.

options.label: C
options.text: Impeachment is a power of the executive branch, while removal is a power of the legislative branch.

options.label: D
options.text: Impeachment is a power of the legislative branch, while removal is a power of the executive branch.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the House Committee on Rules and the House Committee on the Judiciary in the impeachment process?

options.label: A
options.text: They review the accusations and issue a recommendation.

options.label: B
options.text: They hold a separate vote on each of the specific charges.

options.label: C
options.text: They conduct the trial and deliberate after hearing all the arguments.

options.label: D
options.text: They preside over the trial and deliberate after hearing all the arguments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the two-thirds majority vote required for conviction in an impeachment trial?

options.label: A
options.text: It ensures that the accused is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.

options.label: B
options.text: It guarantees that the accused will be removed from office.

options.label: C
options.text: It prevents the accused from being removed from office.

options.label: D
options.text: It requires a supermajority to remove the accused from office.

multiple-choice.question: What are the grounds for impeachment specified in the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: A
options.text: Treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors.

options.label: B
options.text: Incompetence, poor performance, or crime.

options.label: C
options.text: Treason, bribery, or other serious abuses of power.

options.label: D
options.text: Treason, bribery, or other minor crimes.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the impeachment trial of Andrew Johnson?

options.label: A
options.text: He was acquitted by a unanimous vote.

options.label: B
options.text: He was convicted and removed from office.

options.label: C
options.text: He was acquitted by a two-thirds majority vote.

options.label: D
options.text: He resigned before the trial could begin.
